Description: Terracotta figure of a boy playing a lute. A standing youth playing a lute. He is dressed in a short chiton with overfall; a chlamys hangs from his shoulders. The back is plain, with oval vent. The head and feet, previously attached to the torso, do not belong and have been separated. Hollow; two-piece mould. Micaceous brown Nile silt with a drab surface dressing; there are remains of blue paint on the chiton and on and between the legs; yellow paint on cloak; red paint on lute.
Curator's comments: BM Terracotta IV For a discussion of Greek terracottas with lutes, see Higgins and Winnington-Ingram 1965: 62–71. When acquired it was complete with head, feet and plinth. The head (3551) may possibly belong, but it seems unlikely, and there is no ancient join; the plinth with its attached feet (3593) definitely does not belong.
Bibliographic references: Terracotta / Catalogue of Terracottas in the British Museum (3199)
